Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Mitigating the Potential Negative Impacts of Involuntary Online Engineering Courses to Diverse Students’ Sense of Belonging
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to serve the national interest by identifying how the unexpected shift to remote instruction during the COVID-19 pandemic impacts undergraduate engineering students from diverse populations. Specifically, this work focuses on students’ sense of belonging, which is a documented predictor of student success. The rapid transition to remote teaching may result in students facing a “triple threat,” since student’s personal identities, online course formats, and the STEM disciplines themselves each can obstruct development of a sense of belonging in STEM. This treat may be particularly acute for students from racially/ethnically underrepresented populations, first generation students, women, and students from low income backgrounds. The project will carry out its research activities in several online engineering foundations courses that have traditionally been held in-person. Collecting and analyzing data from these courses will be especially important since they generally serve as students’ first postsecondary exposure to engineering and are thus important first steps towards completing an engineering degree.

A multi-phase mixed-methods approach will address the following research questions: (a) How do engineering students perceive their sense of belonging in involuntary remote courses and why? (b) What elements of remote engineering courses are most influential for equitably fostering a sense of belonging for all the students? The project will measure sense of belonging with an existing four-item scale for which the institution has historical engineering student responses. Given the importance of examining sense of belonging in the context of an online course, the Community of Inquiry framework, designed to examine key elements of an online course, is also a component of the study. Sources of data will include surveys of first year engineering students, small focus groups with students from populations of interest, and course observations. The study design affords both examination of the overarching relationships among belonging, student identity, and course delivery as well as in-depth understanding of why and how elements of a course relate to students’ sense of belonging. The impacts of the study’s findings include the potential to help campuses mitigate potential threats facing diverse students currently in remote courses because of COVID-19 and to craft future online STEM courses that avoid such threats. This RAPID award is made by the IUSE program in the Division of Undergraduate Education (Education and Human Resources Directorate).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

This project was designed to examine sense of belonging for first year students from diverse backgrounds (especially across race, gender, and social class) in engineering during COVID-19. The first year of the project examined student experiences and perceptions of learning and belonging while participating in involuntary remote courses, while no-cost extensions of the project supported longitudinal explorations of students' sense of belonging in engineering across their academic experience. In this project outcomes report, we highlight key findings at the conclusion of the grant, while additional data analysis is ongoing.

 

Finding: Possibilities for Belonging & Learning Across Identity and Attendance Type

Examining survey data, we found that comparing across majority and minoritized identity groups (e.g., men and women) as well as attendance type (in-person versus online), groups reported similar experiences of cognitive, teaching, and social presence. In addition, most comparative groups experienced similar levels of belonging, with the only significant difference being that students who attended in person felt a stronger sense of belonging compared to those who attended online. Data suggested a positive design of one specific class under study for fostering student learning and belonging.

 

Finding: Belonging and Learning are Mutually Reinforcing

Examining qualitative data, we found belonging is a conduit for learning. We also found that factors related to peer interactions, instructor behavior and course design, environmental identity cues, and personal and psychological factors influenced (both positively and negatively) student sense of belonging. Implications include the importance of decreasing instructor bottlenecks to peer interaction in online courses, strategies for mitigating negative environmental cues in online environments, and strategies for building courses for learning versus performance.

 

Finding: HyFlex Course Design to Support Belonging

All data from the project suggested one class that was an exemplar of a HyFlex foundations engineering course. Examining the class as a case study revealed four exemplar practices for building HyFlex courses, especially in engineering: (1) encourage questions across platforms (online and in person) in synchronous course meetings, with an assigned monitor for online platforms; (2) use features that allows students to interact with each other and course material across platforms and times (synchronous and asynchronous); (3) use tools that allow students to communicate with one another directly; and, (4) build group projects or components (such as feedback groups).

 

Finding: Sense of Belonging as a Developmental Process

Examining follow up interview data with students in their third year, findings showed sense of belonging in engineering as not just a static feeling but also as a developmental process. Students' meaning-making for belonging, embedded within macro-level environmental dynamics such as intersectionality, developed across engineering experiences or contexts (e.g., classroom versus internship) and time. In particular, many students were able to shift from defining their sense of belonging as tightly tied to grades to defining belonging as related to multiple factors. At the same time, the more a student felt isolated because of identities, the more difficult the process of untethering perceptions of grades and belonging may be. Implications suggest ways engineering programs might not only foster student sense of belonging itself but also help develop their meaning making capacities for belonging.

 

Summary

Overall, the project provided empirical support for the importance of sense of belonging for learning in engineering across online and in-person courses, factors to employ to develop sense of belonging in engineering, ways to design courses to support both learning and belonging, and new ways to think about belonging in engineering and beyond (namely as a developing process educators can nurture with empirically-informed learning environments). Ongoing analysis will continue to yield findings related to constructs such as building belonging across time in engineering, the relationship of self-efficacy and sense of belonging, and factors that support resilience across student journeys in engineering.
